Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Micro-Assembly Exploiting SofT RObotics (MAESTRO)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The MAESTRO project will develop a new type of manufacturing by combining soft robotics and swarm control to construct assemblies in 2D and 3D from individual artificial cells made of hydrogels. MAESTRO will design rules for building tiny factories so that, like a conductor's baton, global control signals will organize artificial cells into complex configurations. These artificial cells can contain living cells and be assembled into tissue for artificial organs, or contain inorganic particles to assemble into micro-scale tools.

MAESTRO will ferry desired components in artificial cells constructed from polysaccharide-based hydrogels. Current approaches use engineered structures or live bacteria as micro-scale actuators to push or pull desired objects into place. The proposed approach uses the soft robots themselves as building blocks for desired patterns. The artificial cells excel at encapsulating a wide range of micro and nano-sized particles, for example living cells and magnetic nano-particles. Furthermore, artificial cells can be triggered to efficiently release their payloads. Novel swarm control algorithms using obstacle-based particle computation will steer the cells. In traditional robotics, simultaneous control of multiple robots is based on individual motion control that requires heterogeneity among robots or the ability to deliver multiple input signals; both approaches are currently impractical in small-scale systems. However, these challenges can be overcome by parallel motion planning in obstacle-filled workspaces. This obstacle-based positional control makes the position of micro-robots fully controllable using just a single control input. Actuation of these stimuli-responsive artificial cells in micro-fluidic, obstacle-laden environments presents a paradigm shift in fabrication technology.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micro-Assembly Exploiting SofT RObotics (MAESTRO) project aimed to integrate micro-scale cell-like actuators named artificial cells and novel swarm control algorithms for micro patterning. The artificial cells were utilized to encapsulate targeted materials into complex patterns using a single global magnetic input. Actuation and control were the main focus for research due to the complexity of the fabrication methods and the integration of the power sources for micro and nanoscale robots.

The initial fabrication of milli-scale soft robots was developed through an economic and robust molding technique using a 3D printer. The soft millirobots were simple and hollow rod-like structures with different configurations of embedded permanent magnets, found either within their deformable-bodies or at their ends. Six different actuation motions were demonstrated: pivot walking, rolling, tumbling, side tapping, wiggling, and wavy motion under an external uniform magnetic field control system. Overall, the soft millirobot platform showed an enormous potential for minimally invasive in vivo applications.

Secondly, to achieve one of the goals, alginate was chosen to encapsulate the targeted material for the formation of artificial cells. Alginate has attracted a significant amount of interest from researchers due to its ability to crosslink in the presence of divalent cations, mostly calcium and barium. The artificial cells were fabricated using an extrusion-based alginate calcium chloride crosslinking procedure. As a hydrogel, alginate was investigated for its motion in fluidic media. However, due to the uncertainties in the fluidic environment, an adaptive controller was designed to improve the closed-loop tracking performance. An update law was also derived to estimate the effect of the fluidic environment. The experiments were carried out to demonstrate the rolling motion of artificial alginate cells in DI water. The manipulation of the artificial cells was performed by single and swarm robots in Newtonian fluidic media. Wall constraints have been applied for the robots to reach a single goal location with two robots starting at different positions in a complex maze.

This project vastly improved the understanding and applications of modular soft robotics. Through the application of an externally applied magnetic field, the development of scalable and versatile soft robots and their manipulation, via a swarm control algorithm, is able to produce large structures. This advancement represents a paradigm shift in how small-scale robotics are traditionally viewed.

Modified by: Minjun Kim

The artificial cells were utilized to encapsulate targeted materials into complex patterns using a single global magnetic input.
